section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: This hands-on programming section introduces fundamental concepts of variables, data types, and type operations in Python. Students will learn to declare variables following Python naming conventions, work with numeric types (integers and floats), manipulate string data, and apply boolean logic. Through practical coding exercises, students will develop proficiency in type checking, conversion, and data type-specific operations essential for Python programming.
learning_objectives: Declare variables using proper Python naming conventions and syntax
Distinguish between integer, float, string, and boolean data types
Perform type checking and conversion operations on different data types
Apply string methods and formatting techniques to manipulate text data
Use boolean expressions and comparison operators in conditional logic
Implement type-specific operations and functions for each fundamental data type

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create variables with meaningful names, understand Python's naming rules, and use different variable assignment techniques including multiple assignment and swapping.
key_topics: Variable declaration and assignment syntax
Python identifier naming rules and best practices
Descriptive variable names and naming conventions
Multiple assignment and simultaneous variable declaration
Variable swapping using tuple unpacking
Understanding variable references and object identity

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables to store personal information including name, age, height, and student status. Use descriptive variable names and display each variable with its value using print statements.
Use multiple assignment to declare three variables x, y, and z simultaneously with values 10, 20, and 30. Then swap x and y values using tuple unpacking, and print all three values.

Create a Python script that declares variables with both valid and invalid names. Include examples like 'my_variable', '2nd_attempt', 'class', and 'student-name'. Observe which names work and which cause errors, documenting the rules.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to distinguish between integers and floats, perform arithmetic operations with proper precedence, and use numeric functions for mathematical calculations.
key_topics: Integer vs float distinction and creation
Basic arithmetic operations (+, -, *, /, //, %, **)
Operator precedence and parentheses usage
Built-in numeric functions (abs, round, min, max)
Type conversion between numeric types
Large number handling and scientific notation

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create a program that performs various calculations: addition of two numbers, division with float result, integer division, remainder calculation, and exponentiation. Display each operation and its result with descriptive labels.
Write a program that converts temperatures between Celsius and Fahrenheit. Use variables to store conversion formulas and display both original and converted temperatures with proper formatting.

Create variables with different numeric values and experiment with built-in functions: use abs() on negative numbers, round() with various decimal places, min() and max() with number lists, and demonstrate type conversion using int() and float().

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create strings using different quotation methods, apply string methods for modification, perform string concatenation and repetition, and format strings using various techniques.
key_topics: String creation with single, double, and triple quotes
String concatenation and repetition operations
String indexing and slicing techniques
Essential string methods (upper, lower, strip, split, replace)
String formatting with f-strings and format() method
Escape sequences and raw strings

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables for first name, last name, age, and hobby. Build a personal bio string using f-string formatting that displays 'Hi, I'm [full name] and I'm [age] years old. I love [hobby].' Apply string methods to ensure proper capitalization.

Take a messy string with extra spaces and inconsistent casing. Use string methods to clean it up: remove leading/trailing spaces, convert to title case, split into words, and then reassemble with proper formatting.

Create a story template using string formatting that incorporates user inputs. Include placeholders for character name, location, and action. Test with different values and demonstrate both f-string and format() method approaches.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to work with boolean values, create comparison expressions, understand truthy and falsy values, and perform safe type conversions with error handling.
key_topics: Boolean values (True, False) and their creation
Comparison operators (==, !=, <, >, <=, >=)
Boolean operators (and, or, not) and operator precedence
Truthy and falsy values in Python
Type checking with isinstance() function
Safe type conversion with try-except blocks

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create a program that takes user input and validates it. Convert input to integer for age checking, use comparison operators to verify age ranges, and boolean logic to check multiple conditions. Handle conversion errors gracefully.

Write a program that demonstrates boolean logic with various scenarios: age verification (18+), temperature checking (freezing/normal/hot), and password strength validation. Show how different boolean expressions evaluate.

Create a function that takes mixed data types and safely converts them. Use isinstance() to check types before conversion, demonstrate conversion of strings to numbers, and show error handling for invalid conversions. Test with valid and invalid inputs.
